climbs.name: Up to the Giant Eastern Flake

content.description:
Climb up to the giant flake on the far right (east) side of the rock. Keep going of course!

Walking off the right side of the rock's probably the best bet.
content.protection:
Bring anything. You'll find a spot for it.

To top rope this route, bring medium slings (10') or larger and use the large rocks and chalk stones on the top of the rock.

content.description: This is a good warm up or second outoor route.
content.protection: You can work all the Sun Slabs from the same anchor. I used to bring a static rope to loop around the horns, but its easier to bring nuts and cams to build a gear anchor.
content.location: Same start as Sun Slab Left, go right at the roof and undercling your way through. Rejoin Sun Slab Left above the roof.

content.description: This is a good warm up or first outdoor route.
content.protection: You can work all the Sun Slabs from the same anchor. I used to bring a static rope to loop around the horns, but its easier to bring nuts and cams to build a gear anchor.
content.location: This route is farthest to the left on the south face. It goes just to the left of the overhang which is part of the Sun Slab Undercling. It tops out in a V notch. Look for the notch and a shrub.

content.description: It does look like some older holds may have flaked off, but this route still goes. Getting up the slab gets you to the crux. Getting over the overhung crux into the crimp pockets is another story. It took me 3 sessions and some help from my friends. It won't feel like its great until you get it.
content.protection: You can work all the Sun Slabs from the same anchor. I used to bring a static rope to loop around the horns, but its easier to bring nuts and cams to build a gear anchor. I can't think of a safe way to lead it. If you fall at the crux, you will deck.
content.location: This route starts directly under the right most corner of the roof that is part of Sun Slab Undercling. It eventually joins with SSU above the roof. The crack to the right is Equinox.

content.protection: Several options for set up a top rope. Use long (30 ft) slings.
content.location: The obvious gully of the east face

content.description: Start 15-20 ft left of the Big Crack and climb up easily to the left side of the 6ft-high vertical slabthat is a bit below mid-height. Â Climb the left side of the slab to cracks which are followed up and back right .
content.protection:
usually TR'd.

For leaders, take a single rack of cams and nuts.
content.location: 15-20 ft left of the obvious Big Crack that splits the East face of the formation

content.description: A nice face climb right of the obvious large crack in the East-Facing face* of the formation.
content.protection:
Usual rack

Easily TR'd from an anchor of wire nuts (and/or cams) and slung blocks.

Don't miss the ancient soft-iron piton driven in just below the "crux"; unfortunately someone has hammered it flat against the rock.
content.location: About 5-6 ft right of the obvious large crack.

content.description: This is a fun root with a nice overhang leading into a crack.
content.protection: Several options for setting a top rope at the top
content.location: The route is on the left of the gully, easy recognizable from the short overhanging section.

content.description: Climb the Arete between the east and the north faces.
content.protection: Several options to set up a top-rope. Use long slings (30 ft)
content.location: This is the arete between the east and north faces of the formation.

content.description: Straight up the center of the rock formation is about a 5.7. If you start to go towards the left of right, becomes an easy 5.6. If you're up for more of a challenge, you can try going up the right to the ridge to the right of the face (not in the guidebook) -- approximately 5.10a/b. :)
content.protection: Good boulders up top for anchors

content.description: East face of the Northern formation, climb the obvious, large, 6-8-inch crack to the top.
content.protection:
Usual rack

Easily TR'd from an anchor of wire nuts (and/or cams) and slung blocks.
